docs.lead_paragraph: New cost-saving methods have kindled hope among some scholars that Medicare could achieve savings just by cleaning out the health care system’s waste.

headline.main: Medicare Needs Fixing, but Not Right Now
headline.print_headline: A First Step On Medicare: Slow Down And Think

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column says that the fundamental partisan argument over how to fix the nation's finances is not about the immediate future, but rather about how the nation will pay for health care as a generation retires; considers government might keep Medicare spending in check by asking older Americans to shoulder more costs, and suggests taking the time to clear out the health care system's waste in lieu of quick solutions.
docs.snippet: New cost-saving methods have kindled hope among some scholars that Medicare could achieve savings just by cleaning out the health care system’s waste.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a strident Republican critic of President Obama’s health care law, said his decision was financial, not philosophical.

headline.seo: Christie Backs Medicaid Help From Federal Government
headline.main: Christie Says He’ll Take U.S. Money to Expand Medicaid
headline.print_headline: Christie Says He Will Take U.S. Money to Expand Medicaid in State

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie, strident Republican critic of Pres Obama’s health care overhaul, says he will accept federal money to expand the Medicaid program in his state; expansion will provide health insurance to 104,000 of the poorest 1.3 million residents currently without it; Christie emphasizes his is financial decision, not philosophical shift.
docs.snippet: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a strident Republican critic of President Obama’s health care law, said his decision was financial, not philosophical.

keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Marc Santora contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Home prices are rising and banks are lending more as well, suggesting that the economy can handle the government cuts that are expected to take effect on Friday.

headline.seo: Reports Show Consumer Confidence and Home Sales Are Growing
headline.main: Report Shows Consumer Confidence Is Growing
headline.print_headline: Report Shows Consumer Confidence Is Growing

docs.abstract: Standard & Poor's/Case-Shiller 20-city home price index rose 6.8 percent in December 2012 from a year earlier, suggesting the economy can handle government cuts that are expected to take effect; sales of new homes jumped nearly 16 percent in January to their highest in 4.5 years.
docs.snippet: Home prices are rising and banks are lending more as well, suggesting that the economy can handle the government cuts that are expected to take effect on Friday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are now ready to stand their ground on spending cuts that will hit the military hard, underscoring what some say was a miscalculation on President Obama’s part.

headline.seo: Democrats and Republicans Miscalculate on Automatic Cuts
headline.main: Acceptance of Defense Cuts Signals Shift in G.O.P. Focus
headline.print_headline: Budget Impasse Signals a Shift in G.O.P.’s Focus

docs.abstract: Republicans are standing their ground on automatic spending cuts, underscoring what some say was a major miscalculation by Pres Obama, who believed threat of reductions in military spending would force party's lawmakers to agree to deficit reduction plan that included tax increases; situation highlights how Republicans dedicated to shrinking government are now more dominant than bloc committed to robust national defense.
docs.snippet: Republicans are now ready to stand their ground on spending cuts that will hit the military hard, underscoring what some say was a miscalculation on President Obama’s part.
